text.body: Was warrior king Greek city state Sparta He led Spartan forces during Second Persian War remembered his heroic death at Battle Thermopylae Leonidas third son Anaxandridas II Sparta

According to Herodotus Leonidas mother his father s niece been barren so long ephors five annually elected administrators Spartan constitution tried to prevail upon King Anaxandridas to set aside his wife take another Anaxandridas refused claiming his wife blameless whereupon ephors agreed to allow him to take second wife without setting aside his first

Anaxandridas died BC Cleomenes succeeded to throne sometime between then BC Dorieus so outraged Spartans preferred his half brother over himself he found impossible to remain Sparta He made one unsuccessful attempt to set up colony Africa when failed sought his fortune Sicily where after initial successes he killed
Leonidas clearly heir to Agiad throne full citizen homoios at time Battle Sepeia against Argos c BC Likewise he full citizen when Persians sought submission Sparta met vehement rejection or around BC
His elder brother king already been deposed on grounds purported insanity fled into exile when Athens sought assistance against First Persian invasion Greece ended at Marathon BC
In August BC Leonidas went out to meet Xerxes army at Thermopylae small force men where he joined by forces other Greek city states who put themselves under his command to form army strong

Whatever reason Sparta s own contribution just Spartiates accompanied by their attendants probably perioikoi auxiliaries total force assembled defense pass Thermopylae came to something between four seven thousand Greeks They faced Persian army who invaded north Greece under Xerxes I

Xerxes waited four days to attack hoping Greeks disperse Finally on fifth day Persians attacked Leonidas his men repulsed Persians frontal attacks fifth sixth days killing roughly enemy troops losing their own

The Persian elite unit known to Greeks as the Immortals held back two Xerxes brothers Abrocomes Hyperanthes died battle On seventh day August Malian Greek traitor named Ephialtes led Persian general Hydarnes by mountain track to rear Greeks

The King thought wise to preserve those Greek troops future battles against Persians but he knew Spartans could never abandon their post on battlefield soldiers who stayed behind were to protect their escape against Persian cavalry

Of small Greek force attacked both sides all were killed except Thebans who surrendered Leonidas killed but Spartans retrieved his body protected Herodotus says Xerxes orders were to Leonidas head cut off put on stake his body crucified
Leonidas Spartan king who famously led small band Greek allies at Battle Thermopylae BCE where Greeks valiantly defended pass through Persian king Xerxes sought to invade Greece his massive army

Ultimately Leonidas his men were wiped out but they bought Greek city states valuable time gave inspirational example only what Greek hoplites could achieve against invading forces but also price Greeks were willing to pay to maintain their freedom foreign oppression

Following Xerxes proposed land invasion mainland Greece BCE Leonidas selected to lead small contingent Spartan hoplites some hand picked men male heirs to defend pass Thermopylae hold invading force until more troops could be mustered
Thermopylae km north Athens excellent choice as point to defend Greece as there mountains rolled down into sea leaving only narrow pass along coast

With Leonidas leading front hoplites fighting their tight phalanx formation they took full advantage their superior armour weapons managed to hold vast Persian army two days However betrayed by local shepherd who told Persians mountain path allow them to get behind Greek lines things looked grim defenders
Ultimately though Greek forces were wiped out to man Apollo s oracle at Delphi been proved right when she stated either Sparta or one her kings must fall

Leonidas son Pleistarchus became king on his father s death but due to his young age Pausanius acted as regent Greeks within year gained revenge Thermopylae victories at Salamis Plataea latter even led by Pausanius nephew Leonidas Xerxes invasion emphatically rebuffed those who fell at Thermopylae were forgotten
A monument set up at site words Simonedes epitaph stating go tell Spartans you who read We took their orders here lie dead stone lion also placed memory Leonidas his men

In ancient art Leonidas quite possibly subject surviving marble statue acropolis Sparta BCE Resplendent crested Corinthian helmet his face inlaid eyes depicts grim determination fallen king became legend
